answer_html: Notice in this example, if the solution vector x has components \(x_1\), \(x_2\), and \(x_3\) then we are trying to claim that \(0x_3=7\) which is never true.Therefore this system has no solution.
answer_latex:
Notice in this example, if the solution vector \textbf{x} has components
$x_1$, $x_2$, and $x_3$ then we are trying to claim that $0x_3=7$ which
is never true.Therefore this system has no solution.
hints_html: Recall that no solution occurs if we have something contradictory or false occurring. Often it is something in the form \(0z=a\) for some variable \(z\) and non-zero number \(a\).
hints_latex:
Recall that no solution occurs if we have something contradictory or
false occurring. Often it is something in the form $0z=a$ for some
variable $z$ and non-zero number $a$.
hints_raw: Recall that no solution occurs if we have something contradictory or false occurring.  Often it is something in the form <math>0z=a</math> for some variable <math>z</math> and non-zero number <math>a</math>.
question: B 06 (c)
sols_html:
We have 3 equations in 3 unknowns so we have a \(3\times{3}\) matrix. In order for a solution to not be found we require an impossible statement to occur. One of the most common ways is to have a line which claims \(0=a\) for some non-zero number \(a\). One such augmented matrix could be

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 0 &2\\ 0 & 1 & 0 &3\\ 0 & 0 & 0 &7 \end{array}\right].\end{aligned}\]

Notice in this example, if the solution vector x has components \(x_1\), \(x_2\), and \(x_3\) then we are trying to claim that \(0x_3=7\) which is never true. Therefore this system has no solution.
sols_latex:
We have 3 equations in 3 unknowns so we have a $3\times{3}$ matrix. In
order for a solution to not be found we require an impossible statement
to occur. One of the most common ways is to have a line which claims
$0=a$ for some non-zero number $a$. One such augmented matrix could be

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0  &2\\
0  &  1  &  0  &3\\
0  &  0  &  0  &7
\end{array}\right].
\end{align*}

Notice in this example, if the solution vector \textbf{x} has components
$x_1$, $x_2$, and $x_3$ then we are trying to claim that $0x_3=7$ which
is never true. Therefore this system has no solution.
sols_raw:
We have 3 equations in 3 unknowns so we have a <math>3\times{3}</math> matrix.  In order for a solution to not be found we require an impossible statement to occur.  One of the most common ways is to have a line which claims <math>0=a</math> for some non-zero number <math>a</math>.  One such augmented matrix could be

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0  &2\\
0  &  1  &  0  &3\\
0  &  0  &  0  &7
\end{array}\right].
</math>

Notice in this example, if the solution vector '''x''' has components <math>x_1</math>, <math>x_2</math>, and <math>x_3</math> then we are trying to claim that <math>0x_3=7</math> which is never true.  Therefore this system has no solution.
statement_html:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a single, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Three equations in three unknowns with no solution.
statement_latex:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a
\emph{single}, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix
of the system.

Three equations in three unknowns with no solution.
statement_raw:
Consider the linear systems described below.  In cases (a)-(d), write a ''single'', possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Three equations in three unknowns with no solution.
